title: 105_hr4082
content: The Small Business Interest Checking Act of 1998 allows for interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses, permitting up to 24 transfers per month. This amendment to Public Law 93-100 aims to provide more flexibility for account holders. SEC. 3. Amendments allow for NOW accounts for all businesses, permitting withdrawals by negotiable or transferable instruments for transfers to third parties. Amendments allow depository institutions to permit withdrawals by negotiable or transferable instruments for payments to third parties. Repeal of prohibition on payment of interest on demand deposits in various acts. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act is amended by removing subsection (g), with the amendments taking effect on October 1, 2004. SEC. 4. PAYMENT OF INTEREST ON RESERVES AT FEDERAL RESERVE BANKS. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow balances held at a Federal Reserve bank by depository institutions to earn interest at a rate not exceeding short term interest rates, to be paid quarterly. The Board may establish regulations regarding the payment and distribution of these earnings. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow balances held at a Federal Reserve bank by depository institutions to earn interest at a rate not exceeding short term interest rates, to be paid quarterly. The regulations cover the payment and distribution of earnings to depository institutions and other entities. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances held at a Federal Reserve bank, with regulations covering payment and distribution of earnings. Amendments include striking certain subparagraphs and sections. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to increase flexibility in setting reserve requirements, allowing for a ratio not greater than 3 percent (which may be zero) and not less than 8 percent (which may be zero).
